title: NIAA meeting: Wooster to remain in I-A in football
text:
NIAA meeting: Wooster to remain in I-A in football Jim Krajewski , jkrajewski@rgj.com 7:53 p.m. PDT September 30, 2015 NIAA logo CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
It was not an easy decision, but Wooster football will remain in Division I-A. 
After more than an hour of discussion at the NIAA Board of Control meeting on Wednesday, the members voted, 5-3, to allow the Colts to remain in Division I-A for the next four years. Wooster will remain in Division I in all other sports. 
That prospect raised concerns among many of those in attendance. They fear that several schools, especially in Las Vegas, will want the same deal. 
Others thought Wooster should move to I-A in all sports. 
Wooster principal Leah Keusher spoke to keep Wooster in I-A in football only and addressed the many concerns of the board. She said with Wooster being the only International Baccalaureate school in the area, many students go there from all over Northern Nevada. 
Playing sports against their former classmates allows them to stay connected. 
“I want to continue to get them to come to Wooster, but not take them away, making them totally solitary by pulling them away,” she said. “It would be a big blow to our school.” 
Wooster played as an independent for two years, before moving to I-A four seasons ago. It is the only school in the state that plays football in a different level than the rest of the sports. 
NIAA executive director Bart Thompson said competitive balance is a major issue nationwide as the board debated the vote. He said some states align every sport individually, meaning schools don’t play in certain classes, sports do. 
Also Wednesday, the first of the two-day meeting, the board voted to return to the previous nomenclature of calling each division classes. The current Division I will be called Class 4A, as it used to be, Division I-A will be 3A, Division III will be 2A and Division IV will be 1A. That change will take effect in the fall of 2016. 
The switch to calling them Divisions was never changed in the NIAA rule book. The Division nomenclature was made to reflect college athletics, which used to have Division I and Division I-A. 
Other items addressed Wednesday included Rite of Passage moving to Division IV. ROP, which used to have mostly boys and competed in Division III in athletics, now has many more girls than boys and about 80 students total. 
Other schools asked to change divisions including Sage Ridge and Sierra Lutheran, which both requested to remain in Division IV. Both are scheduled to move to Division III, but speakers said they are far below enrollment thresholds and expect to remain at Division IV levels, less than 170 students. 
The board will decide the two schools' fates Thursday. 
The Meadows, in Southern Nevada, requested to be kept in Division II. The school is supposed to join Division I-A. That vote was also tabled until Thursday. 
Incline asked that its soccer teams, boys and girls, be allowed to play in Division I-A, instead of their current Division III, saying there is not a state championship in Div. III because of a lack of schools playing the sport. 
But the board denied that motion. 
Later, assistant director Donnie Nelson brought forth a complete soccer realignment, similar to how European leagues move up or demote teams based on their records. 
He said Nevada would have two leagues, a big school league with 14 teams, and a smaller school league with 15. Schools would then be able to change leagues. 
But the board decided to have school superintendents discus the matter at their next meeting before voting on it. 
And White Pine asked to play in the Southern Division III, instead of the North. That was approved by the board 
Also Wednesday, the Thompson recommended having student-athletes register online, instead of with paper as is currently done. One reason is that it would make it easier to track students who change schools. 
Thompson also recommended hiring a political consultant/lobbyist to represent the NIAA at the legislature and between state legislative sessions. 
Both his recommendations will be discussed and/or voted on in January after the budget is approved. 
The board will need to write a job description for the lobbyist position.
